text:
“To the HR who ghosted me after 5 rounds…”

> I stayed up till 2AM preparing for your final round.
Practised my answers, wore my best shirt, smiled.
You never showed up. Never replied.

But guess what? I still got hired.
Not by a better company -
but by one that respected my time and dignity.

To jobseekers: Rejection ≠ your worth.

To recruiters: Empathy is free.

“Your job title is not your personality.”

> I met someone who was a VP at a fintech startup.
He spoke with kindness.
Took the metro.
Replied to every junior’s doubt patiently.

And I’ve met interns who acted like CEOs.

Humility >>> Designation.

Don’t be so busy climbing the ladder…
That you forget how to be a decent human being.

“Why didn’t you just quit if it was so toxic?”

Let me tell you why:

Because rent is real.
Because savings aren’t infinite.
Because interviews take time.
Because self-doubt is loud.

We don’t always stay in bad jobs because we want to.
We stay because we feel stuck.

So if someone finally gathers the courage to leave - don’t say “you should’ve done it sooner.”

Say “I’m proud of you for choosing yourself.”

That decision isn’t easy. It’s brave.

My biggest dream was never to own a mansion.
It was to never look at my bank balance before helping someone.

I’ve always believed that wealth isn’t measured by how much you keep.
It’s measured by how easily you can give without fear.

Since childhood, I had one simple wish -
If someone ever came to me and said,
"I’m in trouble. I need help."
I should be able to reach into my pocket and give -
Without overthinking, without calculating,
Just… give.

I never wanted billions in the bank.
I wanted peace in my heart.
To be financially comfortable -
To eat what I crave, go where I dream,
Pay my bills on time, take care of my loved ones,
And still have enough left to uplift someone who’s struggling.

That, to me, is true success.
That, to me, is living gracefully.

No noise. No luxury flaunted.
Just a quiet kind of abundance -
Where my needs are met, my heart is full, and my hands are never empty when someone needs them.

I don't want to live to impress.
I want to live to impact - softly, but meaningfully.

If I can live a good life and help someone else breathe a little easier -
I’ve already won.

Wake up at 5 AM.
Read 3 books a week.
Build a side hustle.
Learn to code.

Now repeat after me:

I am not a machine.

Productivity guilt is killing us slowly.

You don’t have to do everything.
You don’t have to earn rest.

You’re allowed to just exist.
And that - is enough.

500+ people commented “Interested.”

Not a single one got a reply.

Why?

Because that job post was fake.

On LinkedIn, people prey on jobseekers' desperation just for likes and reach.

If you're posting fake jobs for clout - you're part of the problem.

And to everyone commenting “Interested” - your worth is more than a desperate comment.

Say it with me:
No more begging. No more scams. No more silence.

Not everyone makes it by 25.
Not everyone has their dream job.
Not everyone can afford to quit and “find themselves.”

And that’s okay.

Some of us are late bloomers.
We grow slow.
Quiet.
Unnoticed.

But we still bloom.

If you’re healing, learning, surviving -
you’re already doing something amazing.

Don’t rush.
You’re not behind.
You’re just building roots.

Imagine if candidates behaved like recruiters:
 (aka if karma had a LinkedIn profile)

– Didn’t show up for interviews and later said, “Oh sorry, I was evaluating other companies.”
– Took your product idea, smiled, said “brilliant!”… then used it for their startup pitch.
– Made you go through 6 calls, 3 decks, 2 follow-ups — and then replied:
“Sorry, we’re moving forward with another company that’s a slightly better culture fit.”
– Said they accepted the offer... then never joined. When you followed up, they replied:
“Who dis?”
– Told you they love your company, but want to see what else is out there first.
– Sent you feedback after 3 months saying:
“You’re doing great. Just not great enough for me.”
And best of all?
– Created a “Company Tracker Sheet” with your name in the rejected tab, just to feel something.

If candidates did all this,
you’d call them unprofessional, immature, unreliable.
But when recruiters do it?
“It’s part of the process.”

No. It’s part of the problem.

Hiring shouldn’t feel like Tinder + trauma + unpaid internship all rolled into one.
Fix your process. Or don’t complain when good talent stops picking up your calls.

“Maine kanya vadh kar diya.”
These five words were spoken by a father…
Right after he murdered his own daughter.
A daughter who dreamed.
Who built her career with her own hands.
Who dared to live life on her terms.

Radhika Yadav wasn’t just a national-level tennis player.
She was a young woman with ambition, talent, and independence.
She opened her own tennis academy. She earned money.
And that - was the problem.

Her father confessed:

“Log kehte the main beti ke paiso pe jeeta hoon... unhone uski character par sawaal uthaye... usse bola academy band karo, par usne mana kar diya. Mera maan aur purush ki izzat chali gayi.”

So he waited for the right moment.
He sent his son to buy milk.
Then took a gun…
And shot his daughter four times.

Let’s not sugarcoat this.

This was not just a murder.
This was a patriarch’s final act of control.
This was a bruised ego trying to reclaim power.
This was centuries of internalized misogyny pulling the trigger.

A young woman’s success still brought shame to her own family.

Because she didn’t obey.
Because she earned.
Because she said no.

We do not need more coding bootcamps, fintech startups, or TED Talks until we address the mindset that sees a woman’s independence as an insult.

You can send your daughter to school, to college, abroad even -
But if you don’t fix the mindset that says “she’s still mine to control”,

You haven’t empowered her.
You’ve just educated a prisoner.

To every woman reading this:
You are not responsible for anyone’s ego.
Keep shining. Keep building. Keep fighting.

I know I’ve been missing for a while.
Life threw a double punch - COVID and typhoid - and trust me, it wasn’t easy.

A few days in the hospital, followed by weeks of slow recovery - physically, mentally, emotionally.

Sometimes, you don’t just need rest.
You need to pause.

Health issues aside, life hasn’t been easy lately.
Challenges - some expected, most not - came in waves.

And no matter how strong you are, there are moments where everything feels just… too much.

Breathe.
And be kind to yourself.

That’s exactly what I’ve been doing.
I took a break. Logged off. Focused on healing.

And now, step by step - I’m finding my way back.
Not rushing. Just rebuilding - slowly and mindfully.

To everyone who checked in: thank you.
To everyone else navigating tough times: I see you. Take your time. Healing isn’t a race.

I’m recovering.
Slowly. Gently. One day at a time.

Trying to find my rhythm again - without burning myself out.

If you’re going through something right now - whether it’s physical, mental, emotional -

Please know: it’s okay to pause.
 - It’s okay to fall behind.
 - It’s okay to not be okay.

You owe no one an explanation for choosing your peace.
I’m still in that space - of reflection, realignment, and rebuilding.

I’m coming back - one little step at a time.
